lead_paragraph: The Heads Up Football program has been sold to youth football leagues and parents as statistically proven to reduce injuries, but a review of the evidence tells a different story.

headline.print_headline: Safer Football? Program’s Claim Is Unmasked
headline.main: N.F.L.-Backed Youth Program Says It Reduced Concussions. The Data Disagrees.

snippet: The Heads Up Football program has been sold to youth football leagues and parents as statistically proven to reduce injuries, but a review of the evidence tells a different story....
abstract: Review by The New York Times discovers that Heads Up Football, program of safety courses for youth football coaches heavily promoted and backed by National Football League and USA Football, is not as effective as organizations claim; research and interviews show that frequently cited 2015 study, which argued that program was helping to significantly reduce injuries and concussions, is not accurate.
